node.title: Kellogg Workers Prolong Strike by Rejecting Contract Proposal
node.alt: Workers at four Kellogg cereal plants in the United States have been on strike for two months.
node.description: About 1,400 workers have been on strike since Oct. 5 at four Kellogg cereal plants in the United States over a dispute that has revolved around the companyâ€™s two-tier compensation structure.
node.content: ["About 1,400 striking workers at four Kellogg cereal plants in the United States have rejected a tentative agreement on a five-year contract negotiated by their union, the company said on Tuesday.", "The strike began on Oct. 5 and has largely revolved around the company\u2019s two-tier compensation structure, agreed to in 2015, in which newer employees earn lower wages and receive less generous benefits than veteran workers. Under the previous contract, the lower tier could include up to 30 percent of workers.", "According to a summary provided by the company, the new agreement would have immediately moved all employees with four or more years at Kellogg into the veteran tier. A group of lower-tier employees equivalent to 3 percent of a plant\u2019s head count would move into the veteran tier in each year of the contract.", "\u201cWe are disappointed that the tentative agreement for a master contract over our four U.S. cereal plants was not ratified by employees,\u201d Kellogg said in a statement.", "\u201cThe prolonged work stoppage has left us no choice but to hire permanent replacement employees in positions vacated by striking workers,\u201d the company added.", "Under the agreement, veteran workers, who Kellogg has said make about $35 an hour on average, would have received a 3 percent wage increase in the first year and cost of living adjustments in subsequent years.", "The company had earlier proposed eliminating the cap on the percentage of lower-tier workers and setting up a six-year progression to veteran status. But some employees and union officials saw that as a way to increase the number of lower-tier workers overall. They worried that it could put downward pressure on veteran workers\u2019 wages if those in the lower tier became a majority.", "\u201cAs soon as the lower tier has 50 plus one, they have voting power on future contracts and my wage can go down,\u201d Dan Osborn, president of a Kellogg workers local in Omaha, Neb., said in an interview shortly after the strike began.", "Mr. Osborn said at the time that veteran workers at his plant make about $30 per hour and that they felt especially frustrated by the company\u2019s offer after working long hours, often on weekends, during the pandemic. They believed they had leverage over the company because of a general worker shortage and because some of their skills are specialized.", "Mr. Osborn said he had fixed and maintained machines at Kellogg for more than 15 years, but added, \u201cThere are days, even weeks, when I can\u2019t even get the things going.\u201d", "In addition to Mr. Osborn\u2019s plant, Kellogg workers are on strike in Battle Creek, Mich.; Lancaster, Pa.; and Memphis.", "The company said in a statement in late November that it was able to \u201crun our plants effectively with hourly and salaried employees, third-party resources, and temporary replacements\u201d and indicated that it was hiring permanent replacement workers.", "The strike was part of an increase in labor unrest this fall, including strikes by 10,000 John Deere workers and more than 2,000 hospital workers in New York, each of which lasted more than one month."]
